content.description: This section of rock is not very good. It is grainy as all get out but might clean up decently in time...
content.protection: 2 bolts (the varition starts directly below the top left side traverse of Mumbling Bee).
content.location:
Just to the left and above Mumbling Bee's second bolt...Either go up the first section of "bumbling bee" then drop over to the start of "Woodys Variation" or solo easy gully to the route...

Rap off of exisiting anchors above "Water Moccassin"...

content.description:
Short but sweet slab route on the lower (left) end of Indian Palisades Corridor -- duck around the right side of Willit Pillar, do a short scramble up to your left, and you're there -- almost directly behind the pillar.  The climb ascends the middle of the face past an obvious line of bolts.  It is well-bolted, classic Joshua Tree friction.  Good practice for longer slab climbs like Double Dip, Stichter Quits, and Walk on the Wild Side.  My only complaint is that it's too short!!

Vogel rates this climb at 5.5, but Bartlett calls it a 5.7.  Splitting the difference and calling it 5.6 sounds about right to me.
content.protection: 4 or 5 bolts on the route; I believe there's a two-bolt anchor, although it's been a while.

content.description:
This is an okay route worth doing if in the area.  Start up the easy crack below a large hole 70' off the ground and left of a roof.  Continue up left-facing crack and face, and past chocolate-colored patina plates.

A patina plate can be slung for an anchor.

Descend via low 5th class downclimbing to climber's left.

This is a fun zig-zag crack. Start 10' left of Willit Slab climbing up a groove past an old relic of a bolt stud. Then make some moves left to a crux crack. Fun moves on clean rock makes this a fun one to do while hanging out in the corridor, but be solid on the bottom and middle part as its not to great on pro.
content.protection: Pro to 2" Some thin pro can be placed before heading left but not much till then. A chain wrapped under a boulder was the anchor.We rapped down Willit Slab.

content.description: Starts in the large dish between Eyes of Amber and Water Moccasin.  The crux is climbing through the dish with no really positive handholds.  Once past the dish, easy climbing to the anchor on plates.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chain anchors shared with Water Moccasin.
content.location: Look for the large dish about five feet left of the wide band of white rock that runs up and down the middle of the mostly dark wall.

content.description: Fun and well-protected climbing up positive features in dark-colored rock lead to a nice belay high above the desert.
content.location: Just left of center on the wall and the first route left of the lighter-colored rock.

climbs.name: The Shank
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Steve Powers, Tim Pinar, Frazier Haney

content.description: Cool pumpy moves at the start (crux) to large buckets. A bit gritty.
content.location: Get there by going to the Short Wall area and campgrounds behind it, take path to the right of the Corridors. Faces Morbid Mound. Climb up a few boulders to base of climb. Can be seen from the path.

content.description: Right of serpent scales. 3 bolts and one hidden one way up high, probably added to keep people from killing themselves. Not awesome, but another tick on the wall.
content.protection: 4 bolts, use anchors on Serpent Scales.

content.description:
Locate

Water Moccasin

(5.7); this is the well-bolted, left-arching friction route climbing the right edge of the brown section of the wall.  To the right of Water Moccasin is a lighter section of rock, with a steep section at the bottom.  The Harrell-Turner route (5.10b) ascends the center of this section of rock.

Serpent Scales climbs past four bolts (the last slightly off to the right) along the "scales," which are splotchy, brown patina plates along the right side of the lighter section of rock.

A 50m rope is just sufficient to get you back to the ground.
content.protection: Four bolts to a chain anchor.

content.description:
Crux is about 20 feet up or there about. A few fun traverse moves up top, then up and over left side of formation. Horizontal cracks protect well. Real fun climb!!! (I have a feeling it has been done either Solo or via a TR because it is sort of "right in your face obvious"... None the less, it's well worth doing.

this thing is flat out fun!!!...
content.protection: Two bolts and small to medium cams, no anchors. Use formation on top to sling or build anchor off of.
content.location:
Route is just to the left of "Eyes of Amber" (I think...)

Rap off of exisiting Anchors 20 feet east, above "Water Mocassin"

climbs.name: The Liver is Evil and Must Be Punished
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Tucker Tech, Becca, Tim Pinar, Blitzo, Grant Hiskes

content.description: This route goes up the rather large N. Face of the N. exit of the Indian Palisades Corridor.  It is behind and to the right of the route The Shank, and a ways to the left of the Varnished Wall. This route has bolted (and grainy run-out) 5.10+ direct start, but I believe it's best of come in from the right on easier ground, and then up after that.  Lots of interesting enough climbing, but not a classic.
content.protection: Bolts, a few cams, and some slings to tie off a knob or two.  Bolts on top to rap off of.
content.location: Behind and to the right and uphill from the route The Shank.

content.description: This climb starts up and slightly left clipping bolts along the way. There are chances from small gear to protect the first few moves but the climbing is not too hard. Once about half way up head right towards an obvious short crack  (optional hand size gear if you want). Climb up to a glue-in and good stance below large patina flakes. I climbed left and used the left arete to gain the patina above the first one. You can clip a bolt from the next stance and finish the climb.  When first established, this had some loose scary rock, but the loose rock seems to be long gone.  This is now a popular, fun, and we'll traveled climb.
content.protection: 7 bolts, a glue-in, and a piton. You could use optional small to hand size gear. Three bolt anchor rap.
content.location: This route is located between Willit Slab and Serpent Scales area. Approach is the same for Serpent Scales but stop and look for bolts when you 15-20 feet from Serpent Scales.

content.description: Good climbing past three bolts. There's a mixture of solid great rock and the other kind. Choose wisely.
content.protection: 3-4 bolts to a two bolt anchor rap
content.location: Just past Willit Slab but not quite to Serpent Scales area. Look for two bolted climbs about 15-20 feet before Serpent Scales area.

content.description:
This route is fun, but a scary lead. It's characterized by highsteps onto slopers and good smears. Located near the upper (right) end of the Indian Palisades Corridor, in the white section apparent in the picture attached.

The climb starts low and left of the first bolt, going up to it (10-), past it a ways (5.10b) and continuing up past moves of decreasing difficulty to join the anchors on Serpent Scales, a solid 2-bolt anchor on the belly of a bulge, just before 1/2 rope (0n a 60M).

The climb is fun and rewarding and gets 2 stars.
content.protection: 3 bolts, with a 5.10 crux getting to the first one. The rock is only reasonably solid to that point and a fall before the first clip would be a bad idea, yet within the realm of the very possible. A TR from the anchors after leading Serpent Scales is an option as well.

climbs.name: Eyes of Amber (aka Chivalry's not Dead)
climbs.fa: Alan Nelson, 3/87 (solo),  bolted by - Louie Anderson & Bob Bealle, April 1989

content.description:
Locate Water Moccasin (5.7); this is the well-bolted, left-arching friction route climbing the right edge of the brown section of the wall.

Eyes of Amber climbs past two bolts and a long runout, optionally protected with small trad gear, to the obvious ledge and tree.

A 50m rope is plenty to get you back to the ground, but the tree is on the small side of confidence-inspiring for a rappel anchor.

Vogel describes two routes (Chivalry's Not Dead, 5.7 and Snakes in the Grass, 5.9) in between Eyes of Amber and Water Moccasin.  Neither route showed evidence of bolts or chalk.  In fact, this description MIGHT be for Chivalry's Not Dead, but that just makes Eyes of Amber more ambiguous.
content.protection: Two bolts and some smallish trad gear.

content.description: A pleasant climb that likely earned it's name from the lack of protection. Climb solid patina up the face to a fixed anchor and set a toprope for friends, or access via one of the rotues to the left
content.location: Just to the right of Serpent scales, in the darker rock, the patina creates a smoother bot more solid climb. There is a bolted anchor up top that can be reached via solo or from the top of Serpent Scales.

content.description: This route has a short (15' long) crux section, with a lieback and some fun, exposed face moves.
content.location: This climb is about ten feet right of Willit Slab.
